answers.author: Kathryn Gregory
answers.text:
The City of Peoria, AZ uses a ranking system as one tool to prioritize projects.  Every project in our capital program gets ranked, however, there are a number of other criteria considered (funding source, operational impacts, political environment, etc.)  
Attached you will find the criteria we use.  We ask departments to rank each criteria on a scale of 1-5, 5 being the highest.  We also include some definitions for each criteria.
Also, while it is a helpful tool for looking at the nuances between projects and across project types, it does have it's limitations.   For example, the criteria tends to favor the larger regional projects.  For this reason, we have also created a "Community Works" project that encompasses a number of smaller neighborhood based projects that have an immediate impact on the neighborhoods.  We fund about $1 million a year and these usually include small street projects (sidewalk improvements, Traffic mitigation projects, quick response projects) and quality of life projects (landscape improvements, park improvements, signage).  We have found that these small projects have an immediate and significant positive impact on our residents. 
I have attached a screen shot of the criteria.

answers.author: Allen Fong
answers.text:
The City of San Jose, CA utilizes a bi-annual prioritization process with our City Council to identify priority policies.  Status information for each initiative is provided, including level of effort (from Minor to Major) to assist the Council in determining the highest priority items.  The following link provides additional details on our most recent prioritization exercise in February--http://www.sanjoseca.gov/clerk/Agenda/20120214/20120214_0309.pdf

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
The Center for Priority Based Budgeting, located in Denver, Colorado offers a process for local governments to clearly define goals and priorities and prioritize spending to align with those goals.  This process has been utilized in jurisdictions across the country and focuses on "fiscal health and wellness."   It has met with very positive reviews from managers as well as city council members.  
ICMA has also identified the Priority Based Budgeting model as a leading practice for local governments and is promoting these products and services through its new Center for Management Strategies.   For more information, interested members can contact me at chilvert@icma.org.

author: Toni Shope
text:
A locality is looking for assessment tools that cities use to prioritized projects and what specific critera is used to assess the projects. For example, cities may used a ranking system to determine what projects are of importance for the upcoming fiscal year. Moreover, the criteria for ranking the projects may comprise of a “estimated project cost rating”, “potential revenue rating”, and “ease of implementing rating”. 
If you are aware of such tool please share. 
Thank you,
title: Assessment Tools to Prioritize Projects
